title: Why are people collecting NFTs?
intro: Non-fungible tokens (NFTs) are the latest thing people like to collect? But what are they? Neil and Sam discuss the topic and teach you related vocabulary.
this_week_question: In June 2021, Sir Tim Berners-Lee sold the original source code he used to invent the world wide web as an NFT at a charity auction. The sale started at $1000 but how much did the source code eventually sell for?
a) 5.4 thousand dollars b) 5.4 million dollars c) 5.4 billion dollars
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: desirable objects that people search for and collect as a hobby
having special, unique characteristics meaning that it cannot be interchanged with anything else
a situation where people can do whatever they want because there are no laws or controls
behaving in a different way from what’s normal or expected, often causing damage
any item that is produced and stored as digital or electronic version, for example codes, images or videos and audio files
dishonest business trick or scam where money is used to pay a company’s debt instead of to profit investors

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Neil.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: And I’m Sam.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: People collect all kinds of things for a hobby, from stamps and coins to comics and football stickers. Do you collect anything, Sam?

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: I used to have a big collection of Pokémon cards but I have no idea where they are now.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, maybe you should start looking for them because all kinds of collectables – that’s objects that people want to collect – are selling for big money on the internet. It’s all part of a new tech craze called non-fungible tokens, or NFTs for short.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Non-fungible tokens?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Basically NTFs are unique, one-of-kind items that can be bought and sold like any physical object but only exist in the digital world. ‘Tokens’ can be thought of as certificates of ownership for these virtual possessions.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Hmmm, OK. I understand the ‘token’ part but what does ‘ non-fungible’ mean?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: If something is ‘ fungible’ it can be interchanged, like money for example. With money you can swap a £10 note for two £5 notes and it will have the same value.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: So, something non-fungible cannot be interchanged with something else. Is that because it has special features that make it unique?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Exactly. Imagine something totally unique like the Mona Lisa. You can take a photo of the painting or buy a copy of it, but there will only ever be the one original painting.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: I can see that the Mona Lisa is one-of-a-kind and extremely valuable, but it’s not for sale on the internet!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: True, but lots of other things are, from signed celebrity artwork to virtual football cards. NFTs are like autographed photos – collectors want something no-one else has, even though there’s nothing physical they actually own and keep.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: And the value of NFTs is going up and up?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Massively. A digital sticker of French footballer, Kylian Mbappé, recently sold for £25,000! Which reminds me of my quiz question, Sam. In June 2021, Sir Tim Berners-Lee sold the original source code he used to invent the World Wide Web as an NFT at a charity auction. The sale started at $1000 but how much did the source code eventually sell for? Was it:

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: If you’re asking me how much the internet sold for, I’d say c) 5.4 billion dollars.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK, Sam, we’ll find out later if that’s right.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Sir Tim Berners-Lee famously never made any money from the World Wide Web, insisting that his invention should be free for everyone. But the world of NFTs is controversial and not everyone thinks Sir Tim should be getting involved.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: That’s certainly the view of Shona Ghosh, technology editor at the ‘The Insider’ website, as she told BBC World Service programme, Tech Tent:

transcript.author: Shona Ghosh
transcript.text: I think there’s a balance to be struck between exploring new technologies and Sir Tim Berners-Lee is an amazing figure but NFTs are a wild west . Not everything associated with NFTs are rogue , but these so-called digital collectables are going for lots of money.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Internet NFTs are very new and there are no rules controlling what can be sold and for how much, so Shona describes them as a wild west .

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: The Wild West means a situation where people can do whatever they want because there are no laws or controls, like the early history of the western part of the United States.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: She also calls some things about NFTs rogue - behaving differently from what’s normal or expected, often in a way that causes damage.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Love them or hate them, there are strong opinions on both sides of the NFT debate, as Rory Cellan-Jones, presenter of BBC World Service’s Tech Tent, explains:

transcript.author: Rory Cellan-Jones
transcript.text: To some NFTs are a brilliant innovation which has promised to put a value on digital artefacts . To others they’re little more than a dubious pyramid scheme with a damaging impact on the environment because of the way the tokens are created.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Some people are suspicious of the large amounts of money collectors are willing to pay, comparing NFTs to pyramid schemes - business tricks or scams where money is obtained dishonestly.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: But for others NFTs are a legitimate and useful way to put a price on rare digital artefacts – items, such as images, videos and music, that are produced and stored as electronic versions.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Items like, for example, the original source code for the internet. So how much money did Sir Tim Berners-Lee raise for charity when he sold it off, Neil?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: In my quiz question I asked Sam how much the NFT of the original internet source code sold for at auction.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: I said c) 5.4 billion dollars.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: You were… wrong! In fact it was less - 5.4 million dollars – but still far too expensive for me to collect.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Hmmm, now I’m wondering how much my Pokémon card collection would sell for. If only I could find it!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, while you look for your collection, Sam, let’s recap the vocabulary from this programme all about NFTs which are digital artefacts or items that are produced and stored as electronic versions.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: NFTs are virtual collectables – desirable objects that people search for and collect.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And they are non-fungible meaning they have special and unique characteristics that cannot be interchanged with anything else.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: If something is rogue it behaves in a different way from what’s normal or expected, often causing damage.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: The wild west describes a chaotic situation without laws or controls.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: And finally, a pyramid scheme is a business scam where money is gained dishonestly.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: If you’d like to know more about non-fungible tokens, bitcoin and other trending internet topics there’s plenty to find on the BBC website.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: And for more interesting conversation and useful vocabulary, remember to join us again soon here at 6 Minute English. Bye for now!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Bye!
